chapter_title: Other Applications of the 1 in 60 Rule

questions.question: An aircraft is flying due South. At 1000 hrs, point P bears 267°(T) from the aircraft. At 1006 hrs, point P bears 275°(T) from the aircraft. If the aircraft has a ground speed of 120 kt, estimate the range of the aircraft from point P.
You are approaching Innsbruck, Austria on a glide slope of 3.5°. What height (QFE) should you be at 2 miles range?
You are approaching Rota, Spain on runway 28 which has a glide slope of 2.6°. At what height should you be at 4 miles range?
You are approaching Paris/Charles de Gaulle on a glide slope of 3°. At what height (QFE) should you be at a range of 2 NM?
Using the detail in questions 2-4, what rates of descent (ROD) are required to maintain the glide slopes in:

subQuestions.subQuestionText: a. question 2 if ground speed is 120 kt
b. question 3 if ground speed is 180 kt
c. question 4 if ground speed is 150 kt.

questions.question: On the approach to London Heathrow runway 27, glide slope 3°, you reduce speed from 150 kt to 120 kt. What change should you make to your ROD to maintain glide slope?

You are flying an aircraft into Gioia Del Colle, Italy, on a glide slope of 2.5°. Having had a hydraulic failure, you cannot select any flaps. You approach at 220 kt TAS and have a headwind component of 10 kt.

subQuestions.subQuestionText: a. What rate of descent do you need to maintain the glide slope?
b. With 'mid' flaps and approach speed 190 kt TAS, what change in the ROD is required?
c. What is your new ROD?

questions.question: You are flying an airway with a centre line QDM of 137°(M) towards VOR/DME 'A'. Your RMI reads 141°(M)/DME 90 NM.

subQuestions.subQuestionText: a. Are you left or right of centre line?
b. What is your distance off the airway centre line?
c. Are you in trouble with ATC? (Airways normally extend 5 NM either side of the centre line).
